MACE OF THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY

(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: Honourable Members will wish it to be recorded that this is the first occasion on which a Mace has found a place in this House, or indeed in any previous Legislative Chamber in Singapore.

    Our Mace is the final adjunct of the dignity and prestige of this Assembly, completing, as it does, the accoutrements of the Assembly, the trappings of the Speaker and the panoply of the Serjeant-at-Arms.

    We have in our Mace, first and foremost, a symbol of the authority of this Assembly, and in consequence, it is a symbol of the authority of the Speaker and an emblem of office of the Serjeant-at-Arms.

    I invite Honourable Members to accept that the Mace is an essential part of the equipment of this Assembly and that this Assembly cannot, in future, be considered to be properly constituted unless the Mace be first brought into the House and laid on the Table.

RICE STOCKPILE
(Request for Statement)


    7. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry if he will make a statement regarding the rice stockpile.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to avail myself of this opportunity to make a statement on the rice stockpile though I am sure that most of what I am going to say is already well known to hon. Members.

    The stockpile of rice is part of the Singapore defence scheme and is maintained in the island to cover an emergency. I am sure hon. Members will appreciate that it is imperative that Government should be in a position to issue rice to the public and to the essential services in the event of any emergency either here or in the rice producing countries which results in a temporary shortage of rice. I might add here in passing that the Federation of Malaya also holds a similar stockpile.

    The basic principle behind the stockpile is to ensure that adequate supplies of fresh rice are always available. It is necessary therefore that the stockpile be rotated and this is achieved by requiring

Column: 687

importers of rice for local sale to purchase a certain amount from the stockpile on a ratio depending on the grade of rice. The ratio is two to one for imported whole-grain rice and three to one for broken rice.

    It will be readily seen that the whole success of this stockpile scheme is dependent on regular rotation of the stockpile to ensure freshness of the rice. A new scheme has been introduced recently which aims at a minimum off take from the stockpile of 2,500 tons per month. This will operate for a trial period of four months. Most importers of rice have individually undertaken to draw from the stockpile up to a total of 2,500 tons a month. The principal association of rice importers in Singapore has also collectively guaranteed that offtake would not fall below the minimum figure of 2,500 tons per month. This measure of co-operation by the trade will assist both the trade and the Government.

    As a concession to those importers of whole grain Thailand rice who have given this undertaking, they will be permitted to import up to three times the quantity which they have undertaken to purchase from the stockpile. Hon. Members will observe that the effect of this concession is to lower the stockpile obligations of the importers from two to one for whole grain and three to one for brokens to a flat rate of three to one. Additional imports from Thailand and from other sources will be subject to the normal stockpile requirements.

    I should conclude here by repeating that the stockpile is operated strictly on a "no profit no loss" basis.

    Mr William Tan: Sir, can the Minister give us the percentage of rice which has deteriorated in the stockpile? I was told that as some of the rice could not be moved out, a very large quantity deteriorated.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: As far as I know, there has been no large scale deterioration of rice but deterioration could have set in if Government had not taken this action to keep the stockpile moving.

Column: 688



    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Can the Minister explain why although the price of Chinese rice imported is cheaper by about ten cents a katty it is not included in the stockpile?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, the preference of the consumers in Singapore has always been expressed for Thailand rice and Government has always bought for the stockpile a bigger quantity of Thailand rice. In fact after I became Minister for Commerce and industry I tried to introduce other rice, that is, Burma rice and Saigon rice, and we had trouble with importers here who were forced to take the other grades of rice. However, we are slowly putting into the market rice besides Thailand rice but still the greater bulk of rice that Government holds is Thailand rice because of the strong consumer preference. China has only recently entered into the rice market and the quality of the Chinese rice, I am afraid, is still unknown to the Government as to its keeping qualities, and so on and therefore Government has not thought of buying China rice up to now.

    Mr Tan Siak Kew: Can the Minister inform us of the quantity of the stockpile and the proportion of Saigon rice to Thailand rice taken from that stockpile?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: I have the figures of the stockpile holdings but I am afraid that it would not be right for me to disclose those figures as stockpile holdings are secret. However, the quantity of Saigon rice released in proportion to Thailand rice depends on the quantity of holdings of Saigon rice by the Government stockpile. For the moment, we have about 4,000 tons of Saigon rice and since it was of an earlier import date, we wanted to release this quickly before it could deteriorate. However, we came to an agreement with the merchants only yesterday that they will get 80 per cent Saigon rice and 20 per cent Thailand rice, only for such a period until the Saigon rice is finished. I expect the Saigon rice will be finished in the course of the next month or so and then they will get mostly Thailand rice.

GOVERNMENT POLICY ON LOCAL
INDUSTRY
(Statement by the Minister for
Commerce and Industry)


10.16 a.m.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, though Government welcomes investment in the industrial field from individual financiers and groups with large capital resources, Government feels that the time has come when the people as a whole should not only directly participate in but also benefit by their country's industrial development. Government realises that the working man and woman in Singapore has up to now had very little opportunity or incentive to actively participate in the ownership of industries and to benefit therefrom. Government therefore feels that it is not only necessary but also the duty of an elected Socialist Government to actively assist the people in owning and opening some industries which are profitable because they produce goods needed by the vast majority of the population. Such ownership should not be by the State with publie funds but rather directly by the people on an individual basis so that every individual shareholder benefits directly from the profits.

    In order to achieve this purpose, Government proposes to set up a People's Sector in industry, and some of the industries which produce goods needed by the vast majority of the people and are therefore a portable proposition will be reserved for this Sector in which at least 51 per cent of the shares shall be held locally. Holding of these shares is intended for the working man and woman on an individual basis or for the Government's Industrial Promotion Board. No large local shareholding from this percentage will be allowed.

    In order to organize the working man and woman for the new role of industrial ownership, a People's Investment Corporation will be set up with shares at $10 each to enable every working man and woman to participate by owning at least one $10 share. In order that the Corporation

Column: 690

is really an organization of the people and is not monopolised by a few big shareholders, no person shall be allowed to hold more than 50 shares.

    Initially, as the first target, it is proposed to reserve the further manufacture of cigarettes and the manufacture of matches in Singapore for the People's Sector, and as soon as the People's Investment Corporation has sufficient finances, it will be invited by the Government's Industrial Promotion Board to participate in the setting up of a People's Cigarette Factory with an investment of 49 per cent. Government's Industrial Promotion Board will hold 2 per cent, and outside manufacturers of cigarettes of only popular brands would be invited to contribute up to 49 per cent and to manufacture cigarettes of their popular brands and to supply the technical know how. If such outside manufacturers are not willing to join in the proposal, the remaining shares in the People's Cigarette Factory will be taken up by the Industrial Promotion Board. Restriction will be placed on the import of cigarettes as soon as the factory starts production. It is not the intention of Government to restrict the operation of existing Singapore cigarette factories which were in production on the 13th August, 1958.

    A People's Match Factory would be set up in which the People's Investment Corporation would be invited to invest 49 per cent along with 51 per cent from the Government's Industrial Promotion Board. This factory will be given a monopoly for manufacturing matches in Singapore and imports of matches will be prohibited.

    The Industrial Promotion Board will start taking the necessary steps right away towards establishment of these factories.

    In order to encourage the people to invest in the People's Investment Corporation, a mass investment campaign will be started by the Government as soon as the machinery for setting up the People's Investment Corporation is ready.

CONTROL OF MANUFACTURE
BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.26 a.m.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency the Governor's consent to proceed with this Bill, and I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to assure hon. Members that unless radical changes in Government's economic policy are undertaken quickly, time is running out for us in Singapore and soon we will be facing a situation much worse than what we have recently seen, in the form of gangsterism, because of unemployment, and other anti-social activities.

     Hon. Members will recall that I outlined Government's adoption of a policy of selective protection for local industries in this House on the 13th of August this year, when this Bill had its First Reading that day. I stated in this connection that outside manufacturers wishing to manufacture their products here will, as a general rule, be required to come to an arrangement with the local manufacturer or intending local manufacturer, if any, of the same product or failing which with interested Singapore citizens. I further indicated that such an arrangement should either be on a partnership basis with at least 49 per cent of the shares held by the local interest or on the basis of the local interest manufacturing under licence of the outside manufacturer. If after a reasonable time there is a lack of response from local interests or if such an arrangement cannot be made to my satisfaction, the outside manufacturer will be given permission to set up his own undertaking.

    It might well be asked why Government considers it necessary at this stage to introduce legislation to control the manufacture of goods. The reason, Sir, is simple. It will be quite obvious that if protection is given, some outside manufacturers who up to now have enjoyed

Column: 694

Singapore as a wide open market may suddenly find restrictions placed in their way. They would find that the local manufacturer who up to now was treated by the Singapore Government as an orphan, would now be in a position to capture the Singapore market from them.

    Also the operation of protection would act as an inducement to local capital to invest boldly in new industrial enterprises because they could now hope through Government's intervention to get a fair share of the local market. Thus it is expected that large sums will henceforth be invested by local capital in industries.

    The result of all this would be that some of the outside manufacturers who up to now have been satisfied with supplying Singapore from outside may either have to gradually give up the Singapore market or be forced to open a factory here.

    With the strong consumer preference in Singapore for imported goods, these outside manufacturers opening a factory here and manufacturing their well known brands and marketing them in Singapore again, could have a very tragic effect on local investors. Local investors who might have in the meanwhile invested huge sums and would just be getting on their feet could suddenly find the whole ground cut from underneath their feet by these outside manufacturers and their investment vanish into thin air.

    If no check was exercised to prevent this happening, who would dare to take the risk and invest?

    Up to now, Government has had no powers to check or control outside operators, especially from the sterling area, from opening factories here as and when they liked, provided they did not make big demands on immigration control.

    This Bill, Sir, is aimed at giving Government the necessary powers to exercise such checks.

Column: 695



    Government's aim at present is to ensure that all and sundry are carefully selected before they are allowed to come in. It is only equitable that where a local industry already exists, such local industry should not be allowed to be swamped by outside manufacturers of the same product whose sole reason for coming in at this stage would be to "jump" the protection. However, as I have already indicated, where there is no local industry and no local interest in the manufacture of a product, then the outside manufacturer will be welcomed with open arms.

    In practice, control will be achieved by making it a condition that no person may set up a manufacturing concern here after the 13th August, 1958, without having first obtained a licence. The issue of a licence will not of course absolve the licensee from complying with the requirements of any other written law in force. The licence will be issued on payment of a nominal fee which is not designed as a revenue measure.

    As investment in a manufacturing process is likely to be considerable, it is necessary to provide that a licensee is not at the mercy of politicians more than is absolutely necessary. Thus a licence is made valid for 15 years and renewable thereafter for further periods of 15 years at the discretion of the Minister. Therefore, the licensee has a clear 15 years' run provided he fulfills the conditions laid down in the licence. The Minister will have the power to refuse the issue of a licence or to issue a licence subject to such conditions as he deems fit. In case of such refusal the applicant has no grounds to grumble, because he has not made his investment yet. However, once a licence is issued it is Government's intention that there should be as little interference as possible with the industry and the investor is assured of this by the fact that the licence is to be valid for 15 years.

    There is provision in the Bill for the Minister to revoke a licence if the conditions stipulated therein by the Minister are not complied with, but in such

Column: 696

cases the licensee is safeguarded by the provision that the Minister is obliged to inform the licensee in writing of such revocation and the grounds thereof and the licensee has the right of appeal to the High Court against the Minister's decision. Until the High Court makes a decision, the Minister's revocation cannot be enforced.

    It will be noticed that existing manufacturers on the 13th August, 1958, are exempted as regards goods they have been manufacturing as on that date, but it would be in their interest to apply and obtain a certificate to that effect under clause 12 (3) so that there could be no grounds for doubts later on.

    One other aspect of the Bill is that enabling the Minister to grant an exclusive franchise to a single manufacturer by restricting to him only the grant of a licence for a particular manufacture. Hon. Members will appreciate that it will be difficult to lay down hard and fast rules as to the criteria to be applied before any manufacturer may be considered for the grant of such a franchise. Each application for franchise rights will be most carefully studied and must of necessity be decided on its individual merits. However, the underlying basic principle that will be applied is whether the manufacturer concerned will find it uneconomical to operate having regard to the amount of his initial capital outlay and the size of the local market if a competitor were also to come into the field intending to manufacture the same type of goods. I should emphasise that the grant of a franchise is not by any means intended to restrict or stifle local competition but is a measure which should be available for use very sparingly and selectively as and when the occasion arises. I can, therefore, assure the House that the granting of exclusive franchise rights will be kept to a minimum and will be subject to very close scrutiny.

    This Bill, Sir, will also act as the instrument through which Government could enforce its industrial policy from time to time.

Column: 697



    Now, Sir, getting away from the narrow confines of the Bill to the broader policy announced recently by me on the economic front, we have accepted the principle of protection for our industries. This is a departure from the timeworn, shall we say, half-truth of maintaining the free port status of Singapore. I say that it is a half-truth because it is a half-truth that has been blown up by interested parties to an extent where it has come to be believed in as if it were gospel truth, but the fact is that Singapore has not been a perfectly free port, shall we say. We have had restrictions of all sorts. We have had restrictions on the dollar exchange. We have had restrictions on exports of certain goods to certain countries laid down by the United Nations, embargoes, and so on. An ideal free port should be a trading community which would be occupied only in trade or in matters allied to the trading activities of the place or in services to the community who are engaged in trade. An ideal free port should have no restrictions whatsoever on immigration, currency, imports and exports. That would be an ideal free port but we are far from that. In fact, we have not been an ideal free port to quite an extent, but we have maintained some sort of a semblance to a free port and I am quite sure that if my policies are applied selectively on protection, we will continue to function as an entrepot trading centre without much loss to the entrepot trade and, at the same time, we will be able to give protection and thereby bolster up our industries. However, this policy of protection has got to be administered very delicately and with a balanced outlook and there should be no fear of favouritism in the carrying out of this policy. It is only then that the policy could work. In fact, since announcing the policy and setting up the panel, I have already been swamped by various manufacturers' associations who now feel that they have the right to ask why I have not appointed members of manufacturers' associations to represent the

Column: 698

associations on the panel. I have stood up against it and told them off that I am not going to create any vested interest on that panel. I want independent men capable of exercising independent judgment, not men representing manufacturers - otherwise the Chambers of Commerce will come forward and say, "Where is our interest?" and then you have all the trade unions sitting round a table and quarrelling with one another and you will get nowhere. That is the thing that the Minister has got to fight against in the application of this policy and if the Minister does not fight against that, then I can assure the House that the whole policy may end in Singapore losing a lot of its trade. The key to this policy is the application thereof.

    Manufacturers' associations have come up to me and blithely suggested that I should exclude just five words from clause 12 (2) which reads:

    "The provisions of this Ordinance shall not apply to any person who is engaged in the manufacture of goods on the 13th August, 1958, in respect of such goods."
